title: How to Build Up T‐Cells in Your Body

steps.title: Eat fruits and vegetables high in folic acid, vitamin B6, and thiamin.
steps.content: Eat fruits and vegetables high in folic acid, vitamin B6, and thiamin. These vitamins and minerals can increase the number of T-cells in your body, so try to include them in your daily diet. Studies show that vitamins B6b and B12 help T-cells mature and replicate more effectively. [1] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Similarly, dietary folic acid helps maintain T-cells in various parts of the body, including in the colon. [2] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Thiamin (thiamine or vitamin B1) also supports T-cells and makes them more effective at fighting foreign cells. [3] X Research source One of the best ways to get these nutrients is to eat a varied diet that includes fresh fruit and vegetables. Good sources of these nutrients include: [4] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source Leafy greens Cauliflower and broccoli Peas, chickpeas, and kidney beans Squash Carrots Tomatoes Strawberries Bananas and oranges Nuts Whole grain bread Some fortified cereals

steps.title: Include lean protein and healthy fats in your diet.
steps.content: Include lean protein and healthy fats in your diet. Your immune system needs protein to create T-cells, so it's important to eat foods that are rich in protein. [5] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Look for 3- to 4-ounce (85- to 113-gram) portions of lean meat or protein. Eat foods like skinless chicken, fish, eggs, lentils, beans, and soy. [6] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source Avoid eating saturated fats such as red meats, fried meats, or chicken with the skin. Healthier options include fatty fish high in Omega-3 fats such as salmon, tuna, flounder, sardines, or anchovies. [7] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source

steps.title: Drink at least 1 cup (237 mL) of green tea every day.
steps.content: Drink at least 1 cup (237 mL) of green tea every day. Research shows that green tea contains polyphenols that actually increase the number of regulatory T-cells in your body. Try to sip green tea (hot or cold) throughout the day to get these polyphenols. [8] X Research source If you dislike the taste of green tea, mix in a little lemon or honey to improve the flavor. Green tea is not as potent as other drugs or supplements for boosting your T-cell count, but it comes with far fewer long-term side effects or health risks.

steps.title: Eat fresh or dried papaya.
steps.content: Eat fresh or dried papaya. Papaya is high in fiber, vitamins, and minerals. Studies have also shown that fresh papaya, dried papaya, and papaya seeds increase T-cells and have anti-inflammatory properties, so add it to your regular diet. [9] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source If you're tired of the flavor of papaya, look for papaya supplements at natural health food stores. Follow the manufacturer's instructions regarding dosages and consult your doctor before starting any new supplements as papaya may interact with other medications. [10] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source

steps.title: Include garlic in your diet.
steps.content: Include garlic in your diet. Researchers believe that garlic contains compounds that can increase the number of T-cells, improve their responsiveness, and lower your stress hormone levels. [11] X Research source Try to use fresh garlic in your meals instead of seasoned garlic, which often includes salt. [12] X Research source You can also look for pure dried and powdered garlic at most health food stores. Fresh garlic is also considered more beneficial for you than garlic capsules or supplements, which may slightly salter the composition of the garlic.

steps.title: Eat an anti-inflammatory diet.
steps.content: Eat an anti-inflammatory diet . You can decrease inflammation in your body by choosing foods that reduce inflammation. Since your body must fight most inflammation, decreasing it through better nutrition supports your immune system. [13] X Research source Anti-inflammatory foods include leafy green vegetables like spinach and kale, tomatoes, olive oil, nuts, fatty fish, and fruits like strawberries, blueberries, cherries, and oranges. [14] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source

steps.title: Avoid foods that cause inflammation.
steps.content: Avoid foods that cause inflammation. Inflammation takes a toll on your body and your immune system (and therefore, your T-cell count and/or effectiveness). This puts you at an increased risk for illness and disease. Luckily, it's easy to eliminate the foods that commonly cause inflammation, such as: [15] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source Processed carbohydrates like white bread Fried foods Soda Sweetened drinks Red meat Processed meat like hot dogs Margarine, shortening, and lard

steps.title: Eat probiotic foods or supplements to boost your gut health and immunity.
steps.content: Eat probiotic foods or supplements to boost your gut health and immunity. Although they aren't a cure all, probiotics can help your digestion. They may also improve your gut health, depending on which ones you consume, which is intricately linked to your immune function. Certain probiotic strains like Lactobacillus can stimulate regulatory T-cells and increase their levels. [16] X Research source You can find probiotics in foods like yogurt, kimchi, pickles, sauerkraut, and kefir. [17] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Or, you can buy a daily probiotic supplement instead. Consult your doctor before beginning a new probiotic or making significant changes to your diet.

steps.title: Mind your food allergies.
steps.content: Mind your food allergies. Like inflammatory foods, food allergies and intolerances can cause harmful inflammation in your body. [18] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source This is bad for your health and immune system. It's important that you avoid foods that cause you to have an allergic response. If you suspect you have a food allergy, you should ask your doctor for a referral to an allergist so that you can be tested. [19] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source

steps.title: Learn about your T-cell count.
steps.content: Learn about your T-cell count. If your doctor orders blood tests, the labs can test the levels of T-cells in your white blood cells. Your doctor will discuss any concerns they have if your T-cell or white blood cell counts are low, as well as things you can do to boost your numbers. [20] X Expert Source Farah Khan, MD Board Certified Allergist & Immunologist Expert Interview. 5 January 2022. Increasing your T-cell count is a great way to improve the effectiveness of your immune system. [21] X Research source A typical T-cell count for a healthy adult is 500 to 1,500 cells/mm3 (0.50 to 1.50 cells/109/L).

steps.title: Add a selenium supplement to your diet.
steps.content: Add a selenium supplement to your diet. Studies show that the trace mineral selenium can help your body produce more T-cells. [22] X Research source To easily add it to your diet, take a selenium supplement that contains 55 mcg in a daily dose. [23] X Research source If you're pregnant, increase your selenium intake to 60 mcg a day. If you're breastfeeding, try to get 70 mcg a day. [24] X Research source Ask your doctor before beginning a selenium supplement to ensure you’re getting the correct dosage.

steps.title: Take a vitamin D supplement to activate your T-cells.
steps.content: Take a vitamin D supplement to activate your T-cells. Since it's difficult to get vitamin D from your food, look for a supplement that has 600 IU of vitamin D. [25] X Research source The vitamin can make your T-cells more effective and responsive to antigens. [26] X Research source You can also get vitamin D from sunlight. If you have lighter skin, you’ll need about 8–10 minutes of sunshine a day at noon in the summer (assuming 25% of your skin is showing) or up to 2 hours in winter when the sun is weaker and you have less exposed skin. [27] X Research source If you have darker skin that produces lots of melanin, you may need up to 4 times more sun exposure to produce the same amount of vitamin D as people with light skin. [28] X Research source Consult a healthcare professional before beginning any new supplements.

steps.title: Take a daily zinc supplement.
steps.content: Take a daily zinc supplement. If you don't want to take a multivitamin or your multivitamin doesn't contain zinc, take a zinc supplement instead. Studies show that taking a 30 mg zinc supplement every day for at least 3 months will increase the number of T-cells in your body, boosting the ability and function of your immune system overall. [29] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Consult your doctor before beginning any new supplements.

steps.title: Take a multivitamin for your sex or age.
steps.content: Take a multivitamin for your sex or age. If you prefer to take a multivitamin instead of several supplements, ask your doctor to recommend a multivitamin that contains B vitamins, vitamin A, vitamin C, vitamin E, selenium, iron, and zinc. If your body is low on some of these vitamins and minerals, a daily multivitamin can improve your immune system. [30] X Research source Regular multivitamin use is shown to improve your T-cell count by increasing zinc and vitamin C levels significantly. It also decreases the length and severity of illnesses. Take your multivitamin even when you're not sick. This will prevent a micronutrient deficiency. Consult your doctor before beginning or changing a multivitamin.
